text: And I will fetch a morsel of bread, and comfort ye your hearts; after that ye shall pass on: for therefore are ye come to your servant. And they said, So do, as thou hast said.
text_kjv: And I will fetch a morsel of bread, and comfort ye your hearts; after that ye shall pass on: for therefore are ye come to your servant. And they said, So do, as thou hast said.
text_niv: Let me get you something to eat, so you can be refreshed and then go on your way—now that you have come to your servant.”“Very well,” they answered, “do as you say.”
text_esv: while I bring a morsel of bread, that you may refresh yourselves, and after that you may pass on — since you have come to your servant.” So they said, “Do as you have said.”
text_nlt: And since you’ve honored your servant with this visit, let me prepare some food to refresh you before you continue on your journey.” “All right,” they said. “Do as you have said.”
text_msg: I'll get some food to refresh you on your way, since your travels have brought you across my path."They said, "Certainly. Go ahead."
text_nasb: and I will bring a piece of bread, that you may refresh yourselves; after that you may go on, since you have visited your servant.' And they said, 'So do, as you have said.'
context: Genesis 18:5 unfolds against the backdrop of ancient Near Eastern hospitality, particularly within nomadic cultures like that of Abraham. Hospitality wasn't merely a social nicety, but a deeply ingrained moral obligation rooted in survival. Travelers often faced perilous journeys across harsh landscapes, making reliance on the generosity of strangers essential. Refusing hospitality could mean death. Abraham's eagerness to offer food and rest reflects this cultural imperative. The 'morsel of bread' is likely an understatement, a common rhetorical device to minimize the burden on the guest. While presented as a small offering, Abraham quickly prepares a substantial feast, demonstrating exceeding hospitality. Bread, then as now, formed a dietary staple. The concept of 'comforting the heart' (Hebrew: *leeb* meaning inner man, will, understanding) with food highlighted its restorative power, not just physically, but emotionally and spiritually. This comfort allowed travelers to face the remainder of their journey with renewed strength and hope. The phrase 'therefore are ye come to your servant' emphasizes Abraham's understanding of his role as a host. He acknowledges their arrival at his dwelling signifies their need for his assistance, further underscoring the importance of welcoming strangers in that era. This contrasts sharply with societies where resources were scarce and suspicion of outsiders was common. The quick agreement from the visitors, 'So do, as thou hast said,' signals their acceptance and reinforces the implicit social contract of hospitality.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 18:5 points to several crucial themes. Firstly, it illustrates the grace and humility of God, manifested through the disguised angelic visitors. Their acceptance of Abraham's hospitality reveals a willingness to engage with humanity on a human level. This sets a precedent for God's later incarnation in Jesus Christ, where He takes on human form to interact with and redeem humanity. Secondly, the verse reflects the covenant relationship between God and Abraham. Abraham's obedience to God is demonstrated through his faithful practice of hospitality, a value that God honors and blesses. This foreshadows the blessings promised to Abraham's descendants, contingent upon their own obedience and righteousness. The 'morsel of bread' can also be interpreted symbolically as a precursor to the spiritual nourishment that God provides. Just as physical bread sustains the body, God's word and presence sustain the soul. The 'comfort' offered represents the peace and assurance that come from God's presence, a comfort that transcends physical provision. Furthermore, the angels' agreement to accept Abraham's hospitality highlights their respect for human agency and free will. God, even in His divine form, honors the choices of individuals and works within the context of their lives. This verse, seemingly simple, lays the foundation for understanding God's interaction with humanity as one of grace, covenant, and respect, ultimately pointing towards the redemptive work of Christ.
application: In modern life, Genesis 18:5 challenges us to re-evaluate our understanding and practice of hospitality. We often define hospitality through a consumerist lens, focused on impressing guests with elaborate meals and luxurious accommodations. However, Abraham's example calls us to a more authentic and sacrificial form of hospitality, prioritizing the needs and well-being of our guests above all else. This could involve opening our homes to those who are lonely, vulnerable, or in need of a safe space. It means offering practical help, such as providing a meal, a place to stay, or simply a listening ear. The 'morsel of bread' reminds us that hospitality doesn't need to be extravagant. Small acts of kindness can have a profound impact on others. We can 'comfort their hearts' by offering genuine encouragement, empathy, and support. In our busy and often individualistic society, it's easy to become isolated and disconnected from others. Hospitality provides an opportunity to build meaningful relationships and create a sense of community. This verse also challenges us to examine our attitudes towards strangers. Do we approach them with suspicion and fear, or with openness and compassion? Abraham's willingness to welcome unknown travelers demonstrates the importance of extending grace and generosity to all, regardless of their background or status. Finally, Genesis 18:5 calls us to view our resources and possessions as tools for ministry. We are called to use what God has given us to bless and serve others, reflecting His love and compassion in practical ways. Embracing this mindset transforms our homes into havens of hospitality, radiating the light of Christ to those around us.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the example of Abraham and his generous hospitality. Forgive me for the times I've been too busy or self-absorbed to extend kindness to others. Help me to see the needs of those around me, especially those who are lonely, vulnerable, or in need. Grant me a heart of compassion and a willingness to open my home and my life to others. Remind me that even small acts of kindness can have a profound impact. Fill me with your love and grace, so that I may be a channel of your blessings to the world. Help me to create a welcoming space where people can find comfort, encouragement, and hope. I pray for strength to offer my time, resources, and heart to serving others in your name. Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase 'morsel of bread' is likely a culturally appropriate understatement used to avoid appearing boastful or imposing on the guests. It was a polite way to offer hospitality without seeming overly eager or burdensome.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why does Abraham offer such a 'small' thing as 'morsel of bread'?

faqs.answer: This verse is the beginning of Abraham's extravagant hospitality. It sets the stage for the revelation that Sarah will conceive a son, showing God's blessing upon Abraham's generosity.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to the rest of the chapter?

faqs.answer: 'Comfort your hearts' signifies restoring their strength and well-being, both physically and emotionally, preparing them for the remainder of their journey by providing nourishment and rest.
faqs.question: Q3: What does 'comfort ye your hearts' mean in the context of this verse?

faqs.answer: It reflects the cultural norms of the time where hospitality was a vital social responsibility, driven by necessity in harsh environments and seen as a sign of righteousness.
faqs.question: Q4: Why is Abraham so quick to offer hospitality to strangers?

faqs.answer: Bread, as a staple food, symbolized basic sustenance and provision. It highlighted Abraham's willingness to meet the fundamental needs of the travelers before anything else.
